723708f.text:
Vanderbilt Avenue, north from 45th Street, showing the new arcaded hotel between Park and Madison Avenues, from 47th to 48th Streets, not long after its opening. 46th Street appears as a bridge across the Upper Level platforms and tracks.

In the left foreground, on the N.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 45th Street, is the old Railroad Y.M.C.A. building, temporarily opened from 45th to 47th Streets, and in this block the Hotel Roosevelt will be erected in 1924. On the N.W. corner of Madison Avenue and 46th Street is the Ritz Carlton Hotel, completed in its present form by 1910. The old houses on the east side of Madison Avenue, from 46th to 47th Streets, will presently be demolished. In the left background the tower spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral are seen on the horizon. In the right center, the Possum Building will be built in the block between Vanderbilt and Park Avenues, from 46th to 47th Streets. In the right background may be seen the New York Central Power Plant, east of Park Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, which will be demolished in 1929 to make room for the new Waldorf Astoria. In the eastern half of this block stands the new Adams Express building. Compare this picture with pictures of this part of Park Avenue at various dates from 1903 to 1925.

About 1919.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

723709f-a.text:
Hotel Roosevelt, Vanderbilt Avenue on west side, from 46th to 45 Streets, seen from the north side of 46th Street east of Park Avenue.This is a view which it will be impossible again to obtain from this position, as the new New York Central Building, occupying an entire block, is beginning to rise in the foreground. The Hotel Roosevelt occupies the entire block, from Vanderbilt to Madison Aveues. It was opened in September 1924.

October 12, 1927.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer

730129f-a.folder: 45th Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, Manhattan, N.Y.
730129f-a.text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, East 40's: View 1 is east from 45th Street and Vanderbilt Avenue toward the East River and Tudor City, seen in the right background. On the extreme right is the Graybar Building. View 2 is west between East 17th Street and East 48th Street from Third Avenue and shows the Grand Central Palace on the left, on Lexington Avenue.

View 3 northeastward across Third Avenue and East 42nd Street, showing the "El" and numerous loft and office buildings. The building to the right of the Kent-Ley Garage
Building is the Bartholomew Building.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: October 11, 1927
View 2: October 26, 1928
View 3: July 5, 1940
730129f-a.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - East 40s.
